blogs.title: Why Do People With Certain Psychiatric Disorders Pair Off With One Another?
blogs.summary: It’s not news that when people find a partner to settle down with, they tend to end up with someone who is similar to them in key ways. There’s solid evidence that people “match” along the lines of social class, religion, education

news.title: Patterns of nonrandom mating within and across major psychiatric disorders
news.summary: Couples can tend to be more alike in some characteristics than might otherwise be expected by chance.

news.title: Disordered Pairs: People More Likely to Find a Mate with a Similar Psychiatric Condition
news.summary: The idea that “opposites attract” may seem to hold true often enough, but it is definitely not the whole story: When it comes to choosing a partner, people actually tend to pair up with those similar to them—in qualities ranging from height and…

news.title: Patterns of nonrandom mating within and across major psychiatric disorders
news.summary: Couples can tend to be more alike in some characteristics than might otherwise be expected by chance.

news.title: People With Certain Mental Illnesses Tend To Marry Each Other, Study Shows
news.summary: It's no secret that the old adage "opposites attract" has little scientific basis; you're far more likely to settle down with someone who shares your love for the Sharknado series than someone who doesn't understand the value of terrible CGI.

news.title: People With Mental Disorders Are More Likely To Marry Each Other
news.summary: When it comes to choosing a mate for life, a healthy state of mind is a quality not to be overlooked, according to a team of researchers from the Karolinska Institutet in Stockholm.

news.title: We choose spouses who are like us, right down to our psychiatric conditions
news.summary: We are more likely to choose mates who resemble us in everything from education to body type to physical attractiveness.
